newsitem.title: UK: Dollar feels heat from Dow fall in late Europe.
newsitem.headline: Dollar feels heat from Dow fall in late Europe.

text.p: The dollar came under pressure in late Europe as U.S. stocks tumbled and dollar/mark continued to fail to stick above the key 1.80 psychological level.

The dollar also slipped after the U.S. May trade deficit outpaced forecasts and rose 17 percent, and dollar/yen only managed a brief lift from a hefty 25-percent drop in the U.S.' trade gap with Japan.

"People have been trying to short the dollar all week above 1.80, and they've been cut out each time it's gone above there. They're all fed up and primed to sell it on any move down," said Robin Poynder, chief forex dealer at Charterhouse in London.
The dollar dropped to a session low of 1.7856 marks before clawing back to 1.7890/95 by 1527 GMT, compared to late Thursday's European level of 1.7920/25.
Dollar/yen was at an intraday low of 115.33/38 compared to its previous close here of 116.00/05.

The fall in May's U.S. trade deficit with Japan to $3.63 billion sent dollar/yen to a session high of 116.20. But the market swiftly decided to focus instead on the larger-than-expected overall U.S. shortfall of $10.23 billion.
Despite the dollar's failure to build on this week's 71-month high of 1.8040 marks, market watchers were sanguine.
